Posts.Content: When they told me 3 weeks ago i had breast cancer, i lay there and thought i won't row again, i won't work again, my life is gone.It was terrifying apart from the fact i thought i might die.  I have been training very hard for a national competition in Dec. I am self employed and have a physically very demanding job. Now 3 weeks on i am thinking maybe i can get it back.  If I can just get through the treatment maybe i can work back up to where i am now. I have to have a mastectomy and i am waiting the results of the lymph node biopsy to see if i can have the reconstruction at the same time. I am undecided sometimes,  if i don't have reconstruction maybe i have a better chance of getting back. I really don't know. But can i live with only one breast? people do it.
Posts.Title: Will I ever get my fitness back? Will it be easier if i don't have...

Posts.Content: Thankyou Kacang I have just read the article by Dr Peter Harvey it has been very helpful. People say constantly that i am a "strong person" I run my own business I push myself to the limit physically but i can't control what is happening to me now. That in its self is hard to accept. I have just realised that being anxious about being anxious is a waste of energy I keep trying to calm myself down. Its ok to be anxious its going to be tough and i can't fix this and being upset is actually normal.  The chemo is obviously a really a big thing, I am waiting for the lymph node biopsy results when i get that i will know the next stage at least.  I am starting to face up to the reality of it all. I am looking closely at the reconstruction options, I think nothing, or the stomach fat flap option.I don't want to lose muscles.  But the big thing reading everything is the chemo and it isn't about pushing myself and trying hard.  Dr Peter Harveys article has made me think maybe a change of lifestyle might no be so bad and is something i may have to consider. He articulates everything so clearly, and its ok to feel less than brave and strong all the time, it is a hard thing to experience and recover from. You have actually helped, Thank you.
Posts.Title: Will I ever get my fitness back? Will it be easier if i don't have...

Posts.Content: I am sorry you have to have chemo, I also was hoping to get away without it. Session 5/6 tomorrow for me. It hasn't been as bad as i worried it would be. i have my sessions 3 weeks apart. With the first 3 had nausea for about 5 days. took the anti nausea meds haven't been sick as yet. Was perfectly ok 2 weeks out of 3. With the 4th less nausea more fatigue. I do yoga every day I think it really helps. If i miss i start to ache particularly my neck and back. I do 15 mins stretching at least but usually do about an hour slowly. I try to do 30 mins exercise also on my exercise bike or walking and sometimes i just put music on and dance round the table. Mad I know but i find it lifts my spirits. I was utterly terrified of the chemo but i have luckily not been that bad. I really believe that the exercise helps me.  Its a horrible thing to go through overall but you do get through it. So hugs and good luck. XX
Posts.Title: Going to be starting chemo

Posts.Content: Good Luck Kathryn .b with your op. I had a DIEP flap reconstruction mastectomy and lymph node removal on the 10th of Dec. I am fully healed now, had a slit blip with the abdomen but it is ok now. I have had to have chemo and it has slowed down the healing a bit. I cant believe how good the results are, it has been such a positive thing in the midst of everything else. That may sound strange as losing a breast is pretty horrible, however i look at the results and i am happy. The breast is a good match i have sensation in most of it apart from a small circle and I can wear tops which show  a bit of cleavage! You really cant tell. It makes me feel normal, My stomach is flatter than it has been for about 30years. It was tough going in hospital for the first 3 days very uncomfortable but you know what it was worth it i would do it again. I haven't needed counselling because of my op. I did however need counselling because of the hair loss. I found it totally devastating i still cry about it most days. I had lovely long hair, cold cap failed, i would have done anything to keep my hair. We all have so much to cope with its so tough, but hey we will survive.
Posts.Title: mixed emotions

Posts.Content: Hi I found hair loss the hardest thing to deal with. But that is me, you read some inspirational posts of women who deal with it much better than i have done. I do admire them. it has gone now so in a way its easier now. I would have done anything to keep my hair, tolerated anything, but cold cap unfortunately wasn't working so it was foolish to continue.  I have had very few side effects, nausea for about 6 days which i take the medication for, some weight gain but apart from that i have been fine. Lucky i think so far. I have had 3 sessions now, the FEC bit of the therapy. the T bit is next don't know how i will be with that. The problem is no-one can predict how individuals will respond. You don't necessarily get all of the side effects. Someone advised me not to read them too much. Just check if you notice something.  I have a chart on the wall i cross each milestone off as i get through it and i am halfway now. Downhill from here. The last two things on my list are hair regrowth, and my target weight. the first was my op, the hair, and my 6 chemo sessions. i like to look at the progress it cheers me up. So good Luck Ruby Rose don't worry too much about side effects you are unlikely to get all of them, the nurses are also very experienced and can help manage any that you do get. Love  Marie
Posts.Title: Coming to terms with hair loss.

Posts.Content: Well 2 sessions of chemo and cold cap, week 5 of treatment and losing hair everyday. Wont last 18 weeks. Gave in and went for a wig Saturday. Had Long hair in pretty good condition, people look at me in dismay and said " Oh No not your hair its your crowning glory" Lost it at the Oncology appointment over my hair. Well tried my best to save it but failed dismally. However at the stage where there is nothing worth saving anymore, and gone past upset.  Thought about getting rid of all the mirrors, and not going out for 18 months until I've got hair. But that is totally impractical and absurd. So bit the bullet put on the wig and went to quiz night. You know what? I don't think anyone noticed. Either that or they were being kind. Its really horrible but what choice do we have but to get on with it. I feel really ugly but have to be brave.
Posts.Title: Coming to terms with hair loss.

Posts.Content: 12 weeks out of chemo back at the gym, feeling massively better for it. Getting my fitness and cardio back slowly. Went on the rower when i got the pick line out 13 mins to row 2K dreadful but rowing this in under 10 mins now so progress! Trying to lose weight but not very successfully. have stopped the weight gain but fed up with being so fat. None of my clothes fit. The wig also itches when i exercise. However i am happy that i can exercise. I do spinning and yoga and have gone back to dragon boat racing. I dont know if the difficulty with the weight loss is due to the letrosol or not.
